docs.title: Careers in Microbiology...Horizons Unlimited
author: Goldschmidt Millicent C.
Whitt, Dixie
docs.description: A broad range of present microbiological work is discussed in order to indicate the many possible careers now open in microbiology. Some areas are immunology, environmental microbiology, agricultural, industrial, and food microbiology, and space microbiology. An employment outlook is also given. (MDR)

docs.title: Successful Application of Active Learning Techniques to Introductory Microbiology.
author: Hoffman, Elizabeth A.
docs.description: Points out the low student achievement in microbiology courses and presents an active learning method applied in an introductory microbiology course which features daily quizzes, cooperative learning activities, and group projects. (Contains 30 references.) (YDS)

docs.title: Teaching Emerging Diseases: A Strategy for Succeeding with Nonmajors.
author: Fass, Marion Field
docs.description: Presents a nonmajor microbiology course on emerging diseases that introduces students to basic concepts in microbiology and improves scientific literacy. (Contains 21 references.) (Author/YDS)

docs.title: Multimedia Programs in Microbiology.
author: Kirschbrown, Lita, Ed.
docs.description: This is a catalog of films, filmstrips, slides, video tapes, and audio cassettes. Most of the materials listed are for college or adult levels. The entries contain the following information: title, format, date released, distributor, running time, costs, author, consultants, and producer. Some of the entries bear recommendations or reviews. The entries appear under the following topics: agricultural microbiology, antimicrobials, aquatic microbiology, bacteriology, food microbiology, general microbiology, genetics, history, immunology, infections, laboratory techniques, microscopy, mycology, parasitology, protozoology, virology, and slide collections. (BB)

docs.title: Microbiology of Water.
author: Geldreich, Edwin E.
docs.description: Presents a literature review of microbiology of water, covering publications of 1967-77. This review covers: (1) microbial indicators of pollution; and (2) microbiology of rivers, potable waters, natural lakes, and impoundments. A list of 192 references is also presented. (HM)

docs.title: Women Scientists in Microbiology
author: O'Hern, Elizabeth M.
docs.description: Examines the opportunities and performance of women in the field of microbiology in the past and present. Provides tabulated and graphical data to compare the percentages of doctoral degrees earned by women since 1920 in microbiology, the biosciences, and all fields of study. (JR)

docs.title: Microbiology of Waste Treatment.
author: Unz, Richard F.
docs.description: Presents a literature review of the microbiology of waste treatment, covering publications of 1976-77. This review includes topics such as: (1) sanitary microbiology; (2) wastewater disinfectant; (3) viruses in wastewater; and (4) wastewater microbial populations. A list of 142 references is also presented. (HM)

docs.title: Restructuring a General Microbiology Laboratory into an Investigative Experience.
author: Deutch, Charles E.
docs.description: Describes an investigative laboratory sequence based upon the isolation and characterization of soil bacteria to aid microbiology teachers in providing students with activities that expose them to basic techniques of microbiology as well as demonstrates the scientific process and the experimental analysis of microorganisms. docs.title: Aquatic Microbiology Laboratory Manual.
author: Cooper, Robert C.
And Others
docs.description: This laboratory manual presents information and techniques dealing with aquatic microbiology as it relates to environmental health science, sanitary engineering, and environmental microbiology. The contents are divided into three categories: (1) ecological and physiological considerations; (2) public health aspects; and (3)microbiology of water and wastewater treatment. Each category contains a series of experiments pertinent to that area of study. These experiments outline the purpose, general references, introductory information, apparatus, and reagents. Schematics are provided for comparison of data collected as an aid for data analysis. (CS)

docs.title: Microbiology Teaching in American Dental Schools.
author: Henry, Clay A.
And Others
docs.description: Results of a national dental school survey on microbiology instruction are presented, including data on the integration of microbiology with other courses, placement in the curriculum, class attendance policies, availability of advanced courses, and National Board reviews. Trends are discussed. (MSE)

docs.title: An Activity-Based Format Increased Student Retention in a Community College Microbiology Course.
author: Lux, Mary F.
docs.description: Reports on the modification of a microbiology course to provide the laboratory component at the beginning of the time slot, tailor the lecture topics to relate to the laboratory component each night, and add an outside reading component. Reports that, following this format change, the retention rate increased from approximately 50% to 80%. (Author/MM)

docs.title: Observations on Microbiology Laboratory Instruction for Allied Health Students.
author: Benathen, Isaiah A.
docs.description: The purposes of this paper are (1) to demonstrate that medical microbiology laboratory exercises should be presented with a focus on medical applications, not just traditional microbiology and (2) that exercises devoted to differential diagnostic decision making can be used to enhance the problem solving of students. (PR)

docs.title: Teaching Methods for Microbiology in Saudi Arabia
author: Ameen, Fuad
docs.description: Microbiology as an academic discipline that does not have a long history, but the knowledge accumulated over the past three centuries is rather considerable, and courses in microbiology are commonly taught in colleges and universities throughout the world. In this article, many of the methods that can be used for teaching microbiology in a classroom and laboratory are discussed. In brief, these methods are limited only by the basic technical facilities to which one has access as well as one's own imagination and creativity. The problems, the academic teaching is facing in Saudi Arabia are discussed; most important of them are the use of new technology and avoiding plagiarism.
subject: Teaching Methods

docs.title: Epistemology of Environmental Microbiology.
author: Madsen, Eugene L.
docs.description: Discusses a model that describes how knowledge is obtained in environmental microbiology. Suggests that constraints on knowledge will yield to relationships between methodological innovations and their iterative application. Contains 132 references. (DDR)
